--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "techstuff1971" <techstuff1971@...> wrote:
>
=
> Hi,
> 
> I am new to JUNIT and although I've read all of the docs (save t=
he
> javadoc) it's not entirely clear to me how to proceed or even if JUNIT=

> is appropriate for my needs.  I will explain the situation and was
> hop=
ing that maybe someone could point me in the right direction.
> 
> I have w=
ritten a SQL parser which parses a SQL query and builds an
> object model r=
epresentation of same which it returns as the result of
> a parse.  The obj=
ect model has the ability to print itself and so long
> as the parser works=
 correctly what it prints will be very close to the
> input query.  A singl=
e test case then consists of parsing a query,
> calling printMe( ) on the r=
esultant tree and comparing it's output to
> what was expected, which again=
, is very similar to but not identical
> to the original query.
> 
> So, fi=
rst a general question: I know that his is closer to end to end
> testing t=
han it is to the sort of fine grained class level tests JUNIT
> is designed=
 for.  Is JUNIT even appropriate?  Assuming the answer is
> yes, I'll conti=
nue.
> 
> The pseudo code for a single test case would look like this:
> 
>=
 String orgnlQry =3D "Select * from MyTable.MyColumn";
> String expectedQry=
 =3D "Select * from MyColumn";
> Parser myParser =3D new Parser( );
> // A =
bunch of code to construct Parser and connect to data store
> myParser.pars=
e(orgnlQry);
> SQLTree tree =3D myParser.getTree( );
> String outQry =3D tr=
ee.printMe( );
> assertEquals(outQry, expectedQry);
> 
> I'd like all of my=
 test cases to use the same parser instance so that
> I only have to initia=
lize it once.  The only variables for each test
> than are the orgnl/expect=
edQry pairs of which I've got about 120.  
> 
> I'm able to get a single te=
st case running but I can't figure out how
> to eliminate duplicate code.  =
I'm also no sure how to organize the
> tests.  Shold there really be 120 di=
fferent test methods or is there
> some way to call the same test method 12=
0 times with different input
> strings?  
> 
> Thanks in advance for any su=
ggestions anyone can provide.
> 
> -ts1971
>

- You can separate initializi=
ng code  to setup/teardown method, this
will eleminate some  duplication.
(=
about setup and teardown method, look here
http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc=
/faq/faq.htm#organize_3)


- For 120 different test case, if it has same fo=
rmat and  is in text
file, I recommend writing another class to process rea=
ding it and
return turn each pair. 

Let test case use this class to load t=
hose test cases, this will save
amount of time instead of doing them all by=
 hand.

- Another issue, I think  it's better to divide those 120  cases in=
to
different catagories (ie. simple selection, selection with where
clause =
etc...) . Write a test case for each catagory.  So that when
your code brea=
k you can analyse which kind of sql query is the reason.

I'm quite new to =
JUnit too, so if some expert see any mistakes or any
recommends.  

Hope it=
 helps
